title: 89-year-old inauguration announcer 'heartbroken' after being benched by President-elect Trump
text:
89-year-old inauguration announcer 'heartbroken' after being benched by President-elect Trump Charlie Brotman holding a large inaugural seal from 2005's inauguration in 2009 Credit: AP Our Foreign Staff 10 January 2017 • 9:34am 
89-year-old Charles Brotman has said to be "heartbroken" and "demoralized" after being told he will not be the announcer for the president's inaugural parade for the first time since 1957. 
M r Brotman received an email from the Presidential Inaugural Committee over the weekend informing him that he would not be the announcer for Donald Trump's inaugural parade , US media reported. 
"I was heartbroken," Mr Brotman told news website Circa . 
Once the voice of the Washington Senators baseball team, Mr Brotman has announced every inaugural parade since President Eisenhower's second inauguration in 1957. Time left until Donald Trump officially becomes president 
T he President-elect Trump team decided to break the 11 presidents' worth of tradition and replace Mr Brotman with 58-year-old Steve Ray, a former Trump campaign volunteer and local freelance announcer who has worked with the MLB’s Washington Nationals. 
"I’ve been doing this for 60 years and for somebody to take over the announcing duties from me, I was devastated," Mr told BuzzFeed News after receiving the letter, adding that he was "absolutely demoralized". "I'm devastated." - Charlie Brotman has announced every #inaugurationparade since 1950s. Trump's Inauguration Committee won't let him do it pic.twitter.com/1eA8UFNZ1Z — Shomari Stone (@shomaristone) 6 January 2017 
T rump transition team's spokesman Boris Epshteyn said in a statement that Mr Brotman will be honoured as “announcer chairman emeritus.” 
"Since 1957, millions of Americans and countless entertainers have come to recognize Charlie Brotman as the voice of the inaugural parade,” he said. 
"The Presidential Inaugural Committee will be proud to honour Charlie as Announcer Chairman Emeritus on January 20. We are thrilled for Steve Ray to be introducing a new generation of Americans to the grand traditions of the inaugural parade.” 
Mr Brotman told the Washington ABC affiliate WJLA that he wished Mr Ray well. 
“As opposed to — boy, I hope he fouls up so they say, ‘We want Charlie back.’ No. I don’t want that at all,” he said. Follow Telegraph News
